abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated highly
            satisfactory, with a likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts, achieved through
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower. A
            number of lessons convey the following. In a complex
            institutional capacity building, and policy strengthening
            operations, project successes may well be poorly correlated
            with the allocation of investment resources. This operation
            achieved its most notable development impacts in the
            smallest components, largely due to the successful design
            and implementation, and intervention of an operation that
            was squarely aimed at improving sector management. The
            improved business processes, training, and policy
            development activities paid off, particularly in
            Latvia's reasonably stable macroeconomic and social
            environment. Moreover, the reform's intensive public
            information campaign clearly was a major success factor for
            the multi-pillar pension, and guaranteed minimum income
            reforms; reforms which also benefited from extensive
            technical analyses (e.g., the pension budget model) that
            were made available to policymakers, and the public.
            Nonetheless, the operation might have developed, and tracked
            more quantitative indicators, particularly given its core
            focus on supporting a fiscal, and structural reform agenda
            around social benefits. For complex, information technology
            interventions of this type, it is important to ensure local
            capacity to monitor project implementation, because while
            the Project developed an extremely thorough business, and
            automation plan, this led to a false sense of confidence, in
            that the client was prepared to implement these highly
            technical activities, in the absence of additional support
            (e.g., a project auditor), which highlights the need for
            more careful feasibility, and risk analyses in the future.
            Other lessons outline: the importance of matching consultant
            expertise to needs; the project period was too long; and,
            the Bank project implementation requirements were too
            bureaucratic to ensure timely, and effective
            decision-making, noting some activities were implemented too
            quickly, and, the weak institutional capacity of the
            Borrower, at times, led to over-reliance on external
            experts, and Bank staff.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Welfare Reform
            Project is to support the development of a more efficient
            and effective social welfare system. The project components
            are five in number: (1) improving the Social Insurance
            Department's implementation of social insurance policy,
            and the State Social Insurance Fund's budget management
            and administration; (2) supporting safe, supervised
            privately-managed retirement plans for the Latvian public;
            (3) improving the Social Assistance Department's
            performance in developing policy, and the municipalities in
            delivering local service; (4) helping to implement, monitor,
            and evaluate the welfare Ministry's social policy
            agenda; and (5) project coordination.
